Award.AwardTitle: SI2-SSI: Particle-In-Cell and Kinetic Simulation Center

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Computer simulations using the particle-in-cell (PIC) method are widely used for basic and applied research involving plasma physics applications. For example, simulations that calculate the self-consistent interaction of charged particles aid in the development of new accelerator technologies, new radiation sources, are used in magnetic and inertial fusion research, and help understand the physics of the solar wind. The Particle-in-Cell and Kinetic Simulation Software Center (PICKSC) at UCLA will aim to significantly broaden the impact of PIC simulations by making available and documenting illustrative software programs for different computing hardware, a flexible Framework for rapid construction of parallelized PIC programs, and several distinct production programs. This project will also include activities on developing and comparing different PIC algorithms and documenting best practices for developing and using PIC programs. The activities fostered by this project will bring together an interdisciplinary team of faculty, research staff, post-doctoral scholars, and graduate students. Important goals of this project include also the development of educational software for undergraduate and graduate courses in plasma physics and computer science and will, to build a large community of users through outreach and an annual workshop.

The broader impact of the activities fostered by this project will be significant. A well-documented set of components and example codes for running on large computers and a set of basic production codes will allow students and researchers from all levels and many disciplines to understand the inner workings of optimized PIC and kinetic simulation software used to model plasmas. It will allow them to build their own software, or to make independent comparisons against commercially available codes, against their own codes, and against published simulation data. The availability of production codes to more researchers will increase the rate of scientific discovery. The software will allow computer scientists who are developing tools that allow existing software to use next generation hardware to compare their performances against highly optimized codes, and will provide new code developers a test-bed of parallelized and optimized software for performance comparison. Furthermore, this projet will make state-of-the-art research software available for education, both for physics and computer science courses, will help train the next generation of plasma physicists (in many sub disciplines) and computational scientists. Interactive tools based on simpler skeleton codes will also be useful for undergraduate and high school education. Documenting examples of best practices will save graduate students and new researchers significant time in learning how to best employ PIC simulations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Plasma (at hot ionized gas) is pervasive on earth, in our solar system, and throughout the universe. Plasma physics impacts many fields of applied and fundamental science that impact society. Plasmas are called "the fourth state of matter" because they are fascinating and have very different behaviors than solids, liquids, and gases. Plasmas are extremely difficult to describe purely theoretically and are difficult to study experimentally, so scientists have used advanced simulation techniques to study this unique material and tackle large science projects in fusion energy; astrophysics; semiconductor chip manufacturing; and next generation accelerators for high energy physics atom smashers, medicine, industry, and security, to name but a few. Simulations have been an integral part of plasma physics research since the 1960s. Fully kinetic simulation which  methods are the most accurate but also the most computationally intensive. These methods follow the motion of individual electrons as ions rather than as a hot fluid. The Particle-in-Cell and Kinetic Simulation Software Center (PICKSC) was formed to lead an effort to provide a hierarchy of software tools for carrying out cutting edge research as well as for educating undergraduate and graduate students.

Under PICKSC  a large and engaged user base was cultivated which used PICKSC software to make important scientific discoveries. At the end of the project, PICKSC software had been used internationally by over 45 research groups and 200 users, and used to generate new discoveries described in 50 publications a year. The community of users also shared experiences on the best practices in the use of the software. As shown in figure 1,  users were from universities and national labs throughout the world. The software was carefully designed to enable developers with various expertise to contribute to the project. In addition, effort was made to ensure that the software could effectively use laptops as well as the largest computers in the world. PICKSC software runs on computers with more than 1 million compute processors. The software was also validated against experiment.

The science generated from the software has been featured on the covers of high impact physics journals including Nature and Physical Review Letters. The science discovery enabled by the software could lead to a next generation atom smasher that could shed light on the fundamental forces and particles of nature; to a compact x-ray source for use in material science, biology, and homeland security; and to inertial fusion energy. The philosophy of PICKSC was to let an engaged  user base drive the needed software development. PICKSC alumni have been hired as post-docs or staff at national labs who continue to use PICKSC software. 

Nonlinear, relativistic, and kinetic plasma processes  are intellectually rich and challenging. There is also much intellectual merit in designing complex and highly optimized software that can support simultaneous development of new diagnostics, new physics packages, new numerical schemes, and new levels of parallelism. It is also intellectually challenging have multiple developers while maintaining regression and high performance. Designing activities and documentation so that users and developers at all levels of expertise can be productive is challenging. Balancing the needs of software to be complex yet nimble has much intellectual merit. Designing input files and examples to illustrate complicated plasma processes is challenging.

PICKSC also enabled bringing research software into classroom instruction. These includes instruction on physics as well as on the underlying algorithms and methods. The project generated a series of simulation examples that illustrate complex plasma physics phenomena for undergraduate and graduate students,  as well as examples for beginning researchers. The project also generated small sample code for beginners to understand how to program PIC code on a variety of different computer hardware. These examples are freely available.
